values:
So I finally gave in and joined the Barack Obama train wreck on thefacebook, and here is what I find written on the wall:

Chris Poisson (UIllinois) wrote
3 minutes ago
John McCain and Rudy Giuliani vs. a Woman and a Minority....is there any question who will win the election? Get real all you "college liberals." seriously... 


SO so so so depressing, but this is what I've been saying all along! People have asked me, "Hillary or Obama?" and I reply, "America will not elect a woman, and America will not elect a black man. So it doesn't really matter."  My vote would have gone to John Edwards if he wasn't so depressingly behind in the polls - a former cause celebre now lost amongst the waves of buzz about our two new front-runners. A white Southern democrat with the charm and the politics to take it to the top? Holy Mother of Bill Clinton, I think we've got a winner! But at the same time, he's kind of a has-been, and I don't see why he would put his family through the wringer of another campaign. Lord knows we know what THAT's like.

Today my dad was explaining about Hillary vs. Obama to his intern from Hong Kong. He said that on the one hand, it's nice to have new ideas from someone who's not the last scion of the Bush or Clinton Dynasties. But on the other hand, the President of the United States is charged with (basically) running the entire world, so it would be nice to have someone with a lot of experience under their belt.

I was lucky enough to see Barack address our student body on campus last semester, and goodness knows he's an incredible speaker. He has a lot of ideas that I could totally get behind, but I'm afraid that the bigotry and intolerance of all the Chris Poissons of America is too heavy to overcome.  

Like Nancy Pelosi said, we need a New Direction.  The mistakes being committed now by our parents will take our entire lifetimes to undo. In my life I try my hardest to fight for the things I believe in, and in this case,  I hope to God that 51% of everyone comes along with me.

They say that smell is one of the most primative scents.

I'm more and more inclined to believe them.

Whoever they are.

I got off the plane in Taipei, and even though I was only in the airport, the smells of asia struck me as if I'd never left.  Humidity -- dampness mingled with air conditioning mingled with cleaning products mingled with people with strange scents.

I missed Asia :).

I'm here (Singapore) safe and sound (in case any of y'all were wondering), and am working on getting to Surabaya on Saturday.  It's Thursday at the moment.  Hooray for visa shit.

--Jew

PS: Thanks Ho!  You rawk my socks!

heath, for once i am being ridiculously prompt:

William Morris 9/12
University of Essex
Wivenhoe Park
Colchester CO4 3SQ

Though you might want to check with your post office how they want the country and zipcode written. It might be different.

I'm in photojournalism class right now looking at Reuters photos of Fashion Week in NYC. 

Had a fantastic weekend. Deb's leaving tomorrow morning though. :o( But I was wasted at SC on Thursday, at UCLA on Friday, and at Pomona on Saturday. So all in all, a successful trip, I would say. 

I got tiny jeans from Lucky. Deb says they're not tiny, they just fit me and don't fall off my ass. Oops.

I got a call back for an interview to be an asian peer mentor. So I might get assigned a tiny asian freshman to shepherd through the rigors of USC.

I think I'm also going to apply for the GLAAD internship again. 

meilee

Week 3 of school starts tomorrow. I'm up reading libel law, and what better to do on a Monday night than procrastinate?

Updateage, in bullet form:

- Classes seem awesome. Ran around Griffith Park this weekend taking pictures for photojournalism class, and took a tour of the Shrine Auditorium last week for live music production. Yes, these are classes, and yes, I am a senior. Libel law = not so awesome, but it's required. haha.

- I joined our campus tv station, Trojan Vision, and I quit the Daily Trojan because I effing hate them. I'm now producing a talk show Tuesday nights with one of my London roomies. This week our guest is Perez Hilton, celebrity blogger extraordinaire. Should be hysterical.

- I finally quit smoking. For good this time, I hope. I'm optimistic.

- I didn't work out today, which kind of slays me. But I've been doing pretty well. I'm taking weight training this semester, and that on top of working out on my own has treated me pretty well so far. For the first time I'm smaller than it says on my driver's license. Hopefully I'll keep this up. I'm optimistic, maybe even more so about this than the smoking.

- On one hand, life is perfect. On the other, I'm having the typical readjustment issues that everyone gets on their way back from being abroad. It'll take time for me to get used to everyone and everyone to get used to me. But that's just how it goes, I guess. I miss England a lot, but I think everyone from Europe and DC has been doing a fantastic job of keeping up with each other (Jenny lives six seconds away from me, literally). So 2006 will never really die. :o)

- Bowen and Jodie took me to Whole Foods today. I got hummus and soy nut butter. Hanging out with them makes me feel like a normal person again, which I really appreciate. 

- Deb's coming down to see me next weekend. I seriously can't wait; I have not seen that girl in SO LONG. We have plans to see Benji and Adge and Brian, which is going to be an assload of driving, but it's totally worth it. Hopefully I won't get any speeding tickets this time :o) 

I guess I should get back to reading. And no, Weefy, still no gossip. Sorry. :o) MISS YOU GUYS SO SO SO MUCH.

love,

meiwonk!

Right.  I can't remember if I've actually let you guys -know- this, but I'm coming home.

Work permits have proven to be too much of a pain in the ass, and I'm running out of money.  My most obvious option at the moment is to go and teach in Java, Indonesia.  I'm excited!  I'll probably be coming home in the last week of August, after my Birthday.  I'm going to spend my birthday in London, with some of my friends there, which I'm really excited about, but you bitches better be ready to celebrate again with me when I get back!

Currently, I'm visiting beautiful (but rainy :( ) Granada, and afterwards, I'm going to visit some friends in Valencia.  Then to the UK, then home!

And in answer to your question, Mei, I don't have an address ;).

--Jew

P.S.  I feel as if I now have the authority to say: scuzzy bus stop bathrooms know no borders.

I cannot believe that these past eight months are now over.

I don't think I've ever been happier in my entire life.

I fly home Tuesday night. I've been saying goodbye for so long, and yet it never gets any easier. At all. I'll be home Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, so you bitches had better come see me.

My office took me out to Ben & Jerry's on Friday, and they gave me a card and a pewter jewelry box with the seal of the House of Representatives engraved on the top. I think they liked me. :o)

Being in DC didn't give me any time to mourn London, so as soon as I get back to LA I think I'm going to be pretty insufferable for a few weeks. But you'll get oves. And I promise to stop talking about London...TOO much. haha. 

On one hand, I'm super excited to be a senior at the best school on the PLANET. On the other hand, I'm afraid that I'm going to get tired of all the petty college bullshit too quickly, and go back to wanting to grow up and just be a real person finally, gosh. 

Jewjewbee, congrats on finishing your course! I am so proud of you. :o) (What is your address in Spain?)

2006 is going to be a year I will never forget, filled with people and places and memories that have completely impacted - and in fact changed - the way I view the world. 

A good friend and I were at the Vietnam War Memorial one night last week, and I told him, "I don't deserve this life." He replied,

"None of us do."

Dump trucks and firehoses at 2am. Catalan spoken everywhere. One of the most impressive churches -- you sit down outside of it, and all you can see is sky... and the tip of the ferris wheel of an amusement park right next door. Amazing beaches... covered in people. Good food, better friends. Barcelona seems to be the land of dichotomies... as if it could be this amazing city but somehow... doesn't make it. Don't get me wrong... I've thoroughly enjoyed my time here, met some AMAZING people, learned a ridiculous amount, and eaten even more. But there's something... slightly off about Barcelona. On another note, I'VE FINISHED MY COURSE! Holy shit. The last two weeks were intense. Intense to the point of... going to school at 9 and finishing at 1am about every night. Intense to the point of tears. Intense bonding. Intense teaching. Intense learning. Intense. I passed with a B, which is EXCELLENT. Most people get a 'pass' which basically encompasses 70 percent of people. 30% get a B, something like 5% get an A. There was some controversy about the... objectiveness of the grading, but I'm not going to complain. The work has paid off! I'm currently staying with a friend from the course in Vilanova, and looking into jobs in the Catalunya area (currently looking into one in Terragona, a little south of Barcelona, and one at the North American Institute in Barcelona) as well as seeing what I can find in terms of, y'know, a place to live :). Vilanova is lovely. There's a wonderful festival on, with giants and human castles, and lots of music. It has a much more small town feel (much like Davis, actually), and it's lovely being able to stay with my friend for longer. As usual, I've done something that's created intense bonding... only to have everyone go their separate ways. Story of my life, it seems. Here's some pics o' me teaching... this was the younger groups, aged 8-10. I hope you appreciate me putting them up here, horrendous pictures of me as they are ;). Did I mention how much I love kids? UPDATE, BITCHES! --Jew

After a bit of a failure of a lesson that I taught on Tuesday, the class I taught today was... amazing.  The kids had fun, I had fun, they learned the content, it was AMAZING!  And what's more, I'm now making above standard in the course.  Which doesn't sound exciting, but it is.  It's kinda like making straight As in a demanding courseload.  ANYWAY... I'm walking on air.  Nothing can ruin my day, at this point.  And I wanted EVERYONE to know!

--Jew

1. I love my internship, and therefore my life.  Everyone at work absolutely adores me, or is at the very least indifferent to my existence. I could not ask for a better summer.

2. I am going to see Kelly Clarkson somewhere in central Virginia tomorrow. And then I'm going to Sandusky, Ohio, for the weekend.

3. MTV called me back today, and I think they've decided to give me an interview. (for the fall internship program). Wish me luck.

miss you kids!

meiwonk

Well kids, after a trip that seemed like it lasted about 40 days, I find myself in France.  The trip was so tiring.  It was basically straight travelling for 36 hours on 3 hours of sleep and random hours snatched in airports (and those aren't good, 'cause you're all on edge, thinking someone's gonna jack your bags).  So... it was intense.  I landed in the afternoon, in Basel (on the French Swiss border) and went with my dad and my grandma in to Zurich for dinner.  And we got to drive around and chill, but we didn't get back to the hotel until like... 10:30, and I just passed out until this morning.

Today has been chill, and I expect most of my stay in France to be about the same... we're hanging in Colmar, which is apparently the most beautiful city in Alsace (the area we're in at the moment) -- apparently so beautiful that the Allies wouldn't bomb it in WWII ( this part was under German occupation, of course).  Anyway, it's LOVELY.  It's got a canal (they call it petit venice, for obvious reasons), and some beautiful cathedrals.  My dad and I saw a BEAUTIFUL one, very daunting architecture... like y'do ;).  Then we sat at a cafe, shared a liter of beer, and watched the people go by.  It was excellent.  It stays light until like... 10, or 10:15 pm here, and it kind of throws off your sense of time, but we're doing the whole European thing of eating at 8pm or later.

France is playing Spain, and all the bars are PACKED with people watching the game, and as we were walking back to our hotel from dinner, we heard random cheering from the windows.  In fact, I'm watching the game right now, so I'm going to abandon you folks, but I'm starting to get a real appreciation for the fact that I know NO french, but I can get by a whole helluva lot better in Spainsh.  Nothing like a humbling floreign language experience to make you appreciate what you do have, right? ;)

Anywhat, I'm not going to ramble at you guys too much.. just wanted to drop a note to let you all knwo that I'm alive :).

--Jew

HOLY SHIT FRANCE JUST SCORED!  WOOT!

Well kids, this is going to be the last update for a little bit (not that I've had much to update recently), so I thought I'd make it short and sweet.  Heading off to France at the ass crack of dawn tomorrow morning, and won't actually land there until the evening on Monday.  So... that'll be fun ;).  Hang out with the faja and his mother for about a week, and on Saturday the 1st, I'll fly in to Barcelona, meet my new flat-mate, Carmen, and get ready for some intense English-teaching-learning!  If that makes sense ;).

On a totally different note: Saw Shelby-kun at the farmer's market last wednesday.  He was serving pizza, and I was buying it.  It was almost more awkward than Alison.  Me: Standing in line, pretending I don't see him.  Him: serving pizza, pretending he doesn't see me.  Me: gets to the front of the line, he gives me my pizza, i have to make eye contact.  Him: Same.  Me: Shelby?  Him: Heather?  Me: Been a long time. *makes a run for it with the pizza in hand*.  SO awkward.

And then, as I'm coming out of University mall, what do I hear?  "HEATHER?" Blink. blinkblink.  I look up and it's Diane.  Diane Ghrist.  So we... chat amiably for a couplea minutes, and I run 'cause I'm getting ready to MOVE TO ANOTHER COUNTRY.  But... it wasn't awkward at all.  It was chitchatty, but that's always the way it goes, isn't it?  Very odd.

Last night, hung with Adriel, Adriel's John, Ben, Anna, Jessimica, Deb, and Latanya (sp?).  Smoked, drank.  It was good, chill times.  I enjoyed myself.

Today, I went into the city and met my friend Cris (it's his Birthday!) and we hung out and wandered around and it was /so/ chill and pleasant, as if I weren't about to leave the fucking country.  I love that guy. Some day, you guys will have to meet him.  Oh.  And I dropped into his birthday party for a while, and the first friend he introduces me to?  Goes: Oh!  This is the pirate friend? *facepalm*.  I guess it works both ways, eh?

Anyway, off I go.  Wish me luck.  Email me luck.  LJ me luck.  Love you guys!!!!  HO!  SEE YOU SOON!

--Jew

I joined the U.S. Congress fb network.

who am i.

Home from London!

In Davis until May 27.

Berkeley on Friday for Su-Ho's rockin 21st birthday, then probably off to see the Murph & Co. in SF briefly and maybe Philipe in Oakland. Then back to Davis early Saturday and my flight to Dulles leaves at 2 p.m. on Saturday.

Hit me up if you want to hang out. whee!

mei

Guess where I'll be this summer!!

WASHINGTON D.C.!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

yessssssss.

mei

I made it out alive from Barcelona. My advice: don't take the train.

This time on Sunday I'll be in St. Andrew's, Scotland. And then we're taking a tour up through Loch Ness and the Isle of Skye. I cannot wait. And then Edinburgh. And then maybe Trainspotting (the stage production).

We still need to book Prague, but it looks awesome. I don't know Czech. Or have any idea what the exchange rate is. Oh well, it should be an adventure nonetheless!

Oh, and I got a 35 pound haircut at the local salon, EXM. Long story short, it was the most complicated haircut I've ever gotten (it took like, an hour and a half). AND he changed my part. (HAIR. IN. MY. FACE. *hyperventilation*) So we took a field trip to Boots today to acquire bobby pins, hairties, and styling wax. I currently have two types of "product" in my hair right now. There goes my low-maintenance lifestyle. Oops. 

miss you sluts. what are you doing this summer?

love 

meiwonkers

Yes, I bought these: Officially my most useless, but nonetheless funniest purchase in London thus far. They also had a similar pair with a shamrock on it, but I thought that was a little excessive. But then I bought some with Animal (from the Muppets) on them so...nevermind. ha. - shopping this morning was rough. sorry about the drunk dial last night. :o) - Dublin/random London pics on the fb. meilee

Haven't been around here in awhile, but I'm still alive. Currently recovering from St. Patrick's Day in Dublin...which is really mostly just every American ever plus the occasional swarm of drunken Irish teenagers. Needless to say, I don't really remember a whole lot about yesterday except:

- If you ever get the chance, go to a caleigh (sp?) which is basically like a huge Irish dance party in the street. There was jumping involved. Oh lots of jumping.

- Guinness is really quite tasty.

- Don't try to order things in Ireland using abbreviations (SoCo, Jack, etc.) because bartenders are either slightly deaf or are used to just pouring pints.

- Uhm, Fergus, I guess?

- Uhhm...St. Patrick's Day in Dublin with Brian Murphy and J.D. Hopkins and some HILARIOUS Germans and like, everyone ever. I'm still not over it. 

i miiiiiiiiiiss all of you. I just stalked all of ho's pics on the fb. I can't believe you still have stuff from my roller disco 16th birthday party. can't wait to see you all this summer!

<3 <3 <3 mei

Nothing puts me to sleep faster than reading Kant. Who needs sleeping pills or nyquil when you've got "Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals?"

Blizzard last night. Beautiful this morning. Sometimes, New York City really suprises you.

after three weeks of stressful attempts to pretend like i could trust ross, being utterly frustrated by missing him and completly infuriated by his annoying white boy remarks and attitudes. i've decided that being on my own is best. and the surprising thing is, i dont even feel sad. i feel a lightness and a peace that i havent felt in a long time. 

maybe all this time when i was missing him, really i was missing me. 

i couldnt handle anymore of his arguments with me about how i shouldnt care so much about my grades and my resume. i didn't have the energy to decipher his sarcasm and snideness when he wouldnt tell me what was wrong. i couldnt stand the fact that his actions spoke louder than words, and at the end of the day, i didn't believe he was willing to give as much of himself as i was. 

i was tired of telling him when things upset me, and him respnding with, 'well this is in part because of your own personal issues/insecurities coming out and making our situation harder. if you found inner peace/balance you wouldnt be so stressed out and sensitive.' 

if only you could throw drinks at people across the internet. ;)




mo- don't worry. things will be best in the end. i know it will. someone like you deserves it more than most people i know.
jew- really happy that i got to see you. :) *beamk*
mei- rock on in england for me, keep me updated on the hash and hos.

I'm having a nice day today.

There's nothing better than

Sleeping through parts of lecture, and then calling out your professor in discussion on his attempts to convince us that the concept of Communism was of his own creation.

Being told by a woman in the International Office that you are one of their favorite students, because even when things aren't at their best you're still always smiling and calm.

Walking home and stopping by your favorite bakery to get a chicken salad sandwich on bread baked that morning. Today it was a rosemary french roll.

mmm. All nighter last night, so naptime before next class.

meiwonk

ps: IT'S SUNNY!! AGAIN!!

Sex drugs and rock & roll!  And I apologize now for the bad writing...Su-han's keyboard was crazy.

Random people showing up.

Matty Cakes

Remeniscing with cake and speed2 on high school and how awesome sitting around doing nothing was.  Remember that summer where all we did was dive and play cards.

Su-Han trying to operate a zippo on her leg while drunk and wearing fishnets.

Deb and I playing drinking games.

Smoking cigars with Dom.

I don't actually know anyone here.

Drunk Ryan Yahtze (however you spell that).

Drunkenly wandering the streets of Berkeley.

Life is good.  I don't have to do anything, and people get me drunk.  And I can participate or not, as desired.  I love my life.  Vive Berkeley.

--Jew

Now THIS is fucked up.  C'mon people...

http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20060221/ap_on_re_us/funeral_motorcyclists

--Jew

That's right kids, hi from Santa Barbara!  From Adriel's house in Thousand Oaks, she gave me a ride to Port Hueneme (pronounced wynemi) just on the coast from where she lives.  I stayed there with Shannon and Nic (from the Chieftain) and it was good times.  Seriously, the chieftain people are like a drug.  You can't just go cold turkey after living with them 24/7 for 4 months.  It was a good...weaning experience ;).  AND...I got to go see the Lady.  And spend a bit more time with the people I really miss.  And I met The Man With The Most Beautiful Eyes In The World.  It was an experience, to say the least.  I think I'm going to have to feed my habit once more when the Lady's in the bay area before I head off to Spain.  I'm such a junkie.

So I took the train up here to Goleta and Preston picked me up (bloody train was like half an hour late...).  Basically I've just been chillin' with him and Diana between classes and work.  I met Preston's neighbor, who seems cool enough.  We went on a little stroll through a wildlife marshlands preserve thing and saw lots of neat birds.  and a turtle!  Woot.  It was a bigger version of Finch :).   And we went to the beach and it was rediculously windy.  They cooked me burritos.  It was nice.

I'm heading out tomorrow, spending lunch with Martin in SLO (He's really busy, he has a midterm on Thursday, so I'm just going to stop in) and then I'm up to Berkeley!  My grand tour of Southern California is coming to an end -- and as usual, it's bittersweet.  I'm still going to miss all the people that I'm leaving behind, but I'm really glad I got to see everyone -- and for a decent amount of time as well.  I'm SO excited to be able to see you hot berkeley asians, and I'm one step closer to home.  My parents are all up on my nuts to get me home.  Go figure, right?

Home again, home again, jiggedy jog!

--Jew

yaaaaaaaaaaaaaay.

I'm done with my premedical committee application. 

OMG. I have written a gazillion bazillion essays.

Hamburger Union + pregaming + brownies + more drinking + dancing to bhangra-hop + getting laughed at on the bus + strawberry and raspberry tarts + belting along to the Chicago soundtrack + my darling roommates + the Crawford House Fivesome = one fucking awesome Valentine's Day.

meiwonk!

Ireland was insanely amazing. Photos on the FB. We learned allll about Irish time, AKA everything being maddeningly slow. But I guess Irish people must live longer, as they enjoy a relatively stress-free existence. The flight on the way over played a Snow Patrol song over the intercom; I felt like I was making a pilgrimage to the northern Irish emo boy rockers of my dreams. I just needed to get out of London for half a second, and it was incredible. Madrid next weekend!

Being in Belfast hit me in a way I couldn't have predicted. I didn't know there was a wall separating the two sides, and I didn't know there were still watchtowers throughout the city.  It reminded me of being in Manzanar, except Belfast is still happening now. Apart from being so moving, it reminded me yet again of the futility of religious war.

I love Ireland, even if they can't figure out all their ish. Galway reminded me of UCD, Dublin was so much fun, and I saw some nor cal-esque punks in a pub in Belfast (that was playing the Shins CD, oddly enough).  Felt like a little bit of home a million miles away.

Meilee

all I want to do right now is fall asleep to the sound of your beating heart Me too. I miss you.

So...a few of Ben's brothers thought it would be a really good idea to, after a day of work party at the house, go to Tijuana for the night.  I thought that was a spectacularly bad idea -- especially considering I've just COME from bloody Mexico.  So as we wound down at the end of the day and people were getting ready to go, I was just kinda chillin', reading my book, doing the chilled out thing.  Out of nowhere, Aaron runs into Ben's room and procedes to convince me through the cunning use of gratuitous amounts of flattery.  And then of course, everyone was staring at me, so I had to say yes.  So we all pile in the car (actually 2 cars as there were nine of us) and headed south to the border.  We went with a guy who's cousin always go to TJ, so we ended up in this sort of collection of clubs that was mostly mexicans, not so much white people.  Which was pretty much awesome.  White people can be no so good.  Plus, we had the most amazing tacos and quesadillas.  Mmm.

So anyway, we danced and drank and danced some more.  I got 3 lap dances in the space of like 5 minutes, which was interesting, and the little pledge got his mack on.  About 3:30 we decided we wanted to get going, but there was big drama 'cause more than 5 people wanted to go back...only 3 wanted to stay.  So we ended up going back with a different car load of people, and so when we went through immigration, the new dude (a permanent resident, not citizen) not only told them the truth that he was born in Taiwan, but didn't have his fucking passport!  So we waited for close to an hour for him to come out and, after 45 minutes and a 263 dollar fine, we finally got going.  So late were we, that we got back only 10 or 15 minutes before the guys that stayed behind.  I ended up going to bed at 8am after washing the cigarette smoke out of my hair (but not out my clothes, mingingly enough).  What the HELL was I thinking?  Still, good times at BenJAMIN's.  And now I guess I can say I've been to Tijuana.  Whoo?  There's pictures on Facebook.  Ask Ben about them.  I'm not cool enough to be on facebook.

--Jew
we got so much snow last night. so of course, instead of doing homework .... and

I took Spencer off my buddy list today, just because I found myself checking his profile all the time. 

It's been two weeks, and I'm finally beginning to put that part of my life behind me. It's bittersweet.

So I'm staying with the Fialas, which is awesome 'cause I haven't seen the in a long time.  At the same time, it's really weird.  See, in my house as in so many these days, all the kids have moved out, or are at least off at school.  Here, not so.  Both kids are still in high school, and at that sort of time in life where hanging with your parents isn't cool, being out of the house all the time is the order of the day.  A time of curfews and chore lists, and bedtimes, schoolwork and sports, extra-cirricular activites.  A regimine of school, TV-shows, dinner, dishes.

And here I am, it's like sitting in the eye of a hurricane.  Life goes on at its usual pace, and I get up when I want, I eat when I want, I don't have a job or school.  I can take a 3 hour long walk if I want, or I can sleep 'til noon, or I can sit on my ass all day, or I can do chores if I want.  My world now and my life from before clash, but in a way I kind of like.  It's an amazing contrast that I'm not sure I'll ever have the chance to see again.  I loved my last years of high school, but I'm also extremely excited to be where I am today.

As always, I miss you all terribly.

On a completely different note, I have been reading 'People's History of the United States' by Howard Zinn.  It's depressing to say the least, but it's also incredibly enlightening.  I would just like to say, the tragedy is not that people go hungry during a famine.  The tragedy is that people go hungry when there is food to be had, simply because it is not PROFITABLE to bring the food to market.  Capitalism can bite my ass.

--Jew

Hooray for being on land!  *dance*  I saw the Chieftain move for the first time in 100 days without me ;).  It was interesting.

Watched the superbowl with people I had just met.  
Woo?

I have rediculous amounts of stuff.

I get to see BenJAMIN!  And Adriel!  And Preston!  I'm excited!

I'm in the US!  Call me, bitches!

--Jew

Look how cool we are:

http://www.city.ac.uk/international/study_abroad/student_photo-album.html

meilee

PS: What are your favorite drinks?  I'm not creative and running out of things to order at bars. ha!

pss: MISS YOU!

Break ups suck.

I have my up moments and my down moments.

Does anyone have any suggestions for good break up songs? Like the non-depressing kind? There's only so many times I can listen to Kelly Clarkson's "Since U Been Gone." >.<

Well kids, today is a red banner day, for Heather Kelleher down here in Cabo San Lucas.  Not only have we stopped the soul-stealing process of painting a rusty steel ketch, but we have also gotten a dock.  That's right, ladies and gentlemen, my feet are on dry land.  I won't have to be up for a random hour during the night, and I plan to get PLASTERED.  It shall be awesome.  As if all that weren't enough, we got half a day off.  Woot!  I can't remember the last half day off we got, but this is awesome.  So awesome.  AND we're leaving tommorrow!  Tomorrow I'm starting the journey back to the states -- which will be my first trip to the US this year.  Heehee.  I just like saying that.  I'm so excited, I can't even articlate properly.

You know when daffy duck gets really excited and he bounces around going, "Woohoowoohoowoohoo!"?  That's what I feel like doing.  Woot!

Ho - WIERDNESS with Ross.  I hope it all works out.  Don't work yourself to death, hun!  Look forward to seeing you soon :).

Mei - You crazy asian.  I'm glad you're having enough adventures for the both of us!

Lis - Keep those freshmen in line.

--Jew

Well kids, greetings from Cabo, tourist capital of Baja California.  It's awful.  We've got a fuckoff huge cruise ship as a neighbor in the anchorage, and the dubious company of countless jetskis and parasailors making the rounds.  Other than that, the scenery is dramatic and lovely.  Huge cliffs rising out of the sea, endless sandy beaches...it's lovely.  What's also lovely is that we're done pounding into a headsea.  We've been bounced around for the last four or five days and we're happy to be out of it finally.

In other news, I was actually able to use a proper BLANKET last night.  It was a real step forward.  I feel like I've grown a little.  Hooray for blankets!

The end is in sight!  Finally ;).  It looks like we're going to be here in Cabo for a week or so painting the boat (which is about the most unglamorous thing you can think of.  It involves a lot of sanding, respirators, hanging over the side in bosun's chairs for so long you can't feel your legs, and paint so toxic you have to coat yourself in latex to be able to use it -- needless to say, I'm not allowed near the stuff).  After that, it's only the transit from Cabo San Lucas (which is at the southern tip of Baja California) up to LA, and I'm finished!  I will have made the WHOLE BLOODY JOURNEY!  And I'll be able to see you bitches.  I miss you guys tons!  If any excitement happens in Cabo, I'll let you know.  I'm not optimistic.

--Jew

And so it begins: another round of 21st birthday parties.

My friend got a table at Le Souk, which is renowned for its extraordinarily good looking actors/dancers/singers waiting staff. Club hopping after that. Must do B8, PM, and maybe APT.

I ran into Brittany Mohr at a bar last night.

I met a guy who knows JD Hopkins. 

Hella NYU students just moved into my building. And they brought their RAs with them.

what the eff. London is weird. I love it.

meilee

EDIT: WE SAW 50 CENT IN LEICESTER SQUARE. I thought I left america to GET AWAY from 50 Cent, wtf.

Thankfully, Jenny is always prepared with her digital camera to document every idiotic thing that I do, all semester long. a) Apparently, the "P1" button on the washing machine here means, "Oh, I will now wash your clothes for over an hour in water heated to 90 degrees celsius. Cheers, stupid American!" b) TINY, TINY SOCKS. c) Go Nittany Lions! that is all. meilee ps: after three whole days of being a drinker, my mojitos tonight caused Jenny to declare me her "favorite bartender." I win!

Packing. My last 5 hours in California. This has been a rather disappointing Winter Break all things considered, from my lack of productivity to all my friends who just ... disappeared. Boo.

Lissy

Doing socially destructive things in State College, Pennsylvania.

Fuck Texas.

Meilee
